DOC.HEAD: McLucas Named To Head SEC Enforcement
DOC.TEXT: William C. McLucas, a senior lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission, was named today as the new head of enforcement of the SEC. SEC Chairman Richard Breeden, in his first major decision since taking over as head of the SEC in October, made the announcement of McLucas' appointment at a news conference. The nomination of an enforcement director does not require Senate confirmation, but it is considered the second-most powerful position at the agency because it is the enforcement division which has the job of policing the multibillion-dollar securities industry. McLucas, a senior SEC enforcement lawyer, had been considered a top contender to get the nod to succeed Gary Lynch, who announced he was stepping down last May after serving for four years as the head of enforcement. Lynch received widespread praise for the job he did in breaking open a series of big insider trading cases, beginning with the exposure of stockbroker Dennis Levine, continuing through a $100 million settlement with speculator Ivan Boesky and culminating with the settlement of a massive civil fraud case with junk bond-giant Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Lynch took over the enforcement division at a time of turmoil for the SEC after his predecessor, John Fedders, stepped down amid allegations that he beat his wife. Lynch was credited with restoring morale at the agency and spearheading a series of major investigations. In May 1986, the SEC filed charges against Levine, whose cooperation led to Boesky, who in turn implicated Drexel Burnham in the largest securities fraud case ever brought by the government. The scandals in recent years have forced Wall Street's big brokerage houses to re-evaluate their compliance and ethics codes and led Congress to increase the penalties for insider trading.
